item.title: Searching-for-the-cookie
item.description: Objective: Exploit an XSS vulnerability to retrieve the session cookie (the flag).The target is a simple image search website. The challenge title hints strongly at an XSS vulnerability related to cookies. A search box was identified as the primary user input. Entering a test string (e.g., test) showed the input being reflected directly onto the page. Viewing the page source revealed the critical detail: the user input was inserted within an existing <script> block in the DOM. document.write('<img src="/images/' + user_input + '"/>'); This indicated a DOM-based XSS vulnerability where we could break out of the JavaScript string and inject arbitrary code. The goal was to close the existing <script> tag and start a new one to execute our code. Initial Attempt: Simply closing the script string and statement with '};alert(1) failed, as the input was still being treated as data within the original script. Successful Payload: The solution was to close the entire <script> tag itself and define a new one: Payload: </script><script>alert(document.cookie)</script> This payload successfully terminated the original script block and created a new, attacker-controlled script block. The crafted payload was entered into the search box and submitted. A JavaScript alert popped up, displaying the contents of document.cookie. The flag was contained within the cookie value. Flag: [The flag would be displayed in the alert box]This challenge demonstrated a classic DOM-based XSS attack. The key to exploitation was understanding the context of the injection (inside a <script> tag) and using the correct method to escape that context (</script> tag closure) rather than just escaping the JavaScript string. Proper output encoding and the use of Content Security Policy (CSP) are effective mitigations against such attacks.
